STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 8, 2023
Jennifer Schmidt
MECOSTA/OSCEOLA DHHS
800 WATER TOWER RD,
BIG RAPIDS, MI, 49307-2161
Re: License #: CP540201288
Dear Jennifer Schmidt:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
November 7, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

Services

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(4) Before completion of the written report required
by subrule (6) of this rule, an agency shall provide
the foster parent with a verbal summary of the
preliminary findings at the conclusion of the
evaluation.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not have documentation verbal
summary of findings were provided to the foster parent as required.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was provided a copy of the report within 10 calendar days of completion as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/28/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/17/2022
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
2

(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the
foster child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in
the child’s placement at least once every month.
One of three foster care files reviewed did not have monthly visitation with the
worker and child in the foster placement as required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned
change of placement or no later than three business
days after an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
step-down from a residential or hospital setting,
return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
One of three foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
3

The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
Three of three foster care files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or
the DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/28/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/17/2022
FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have
been found to produce positive outcomes for
children in foster care. A quality visit is defined as
one in which the caseworker:
• Can meet with each child individually, without the
presence of other individuals, to give the child an
opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss
the current placement.
• Views the child's bedroom and sleeping
arrangements.
• Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for
infants under 12 months.
• Assesses each child’s educational, medical,
dental, mental health and other needs and takes
appropriate action or offers services in response
to the identified needs of each child.
• Shows interest in the child to build and establish
rapport.
Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan
for parenting time, visits with siblings and other
relatives, and the child's permanency plan, in a
developmentally appropriate way while allowing the
child to ask questions and express viewpoints.
One of three foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation of a quality
visit.
4

FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans
within 14 days of the end of the report period.
One of three foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case
service plan within 14 days as required.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any
youth aged 14 and older and in the case of placement
agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Three of three foster care files reviewed (7 of 14 service plans) did not contain all of
the required signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/28/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/17/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Date on document needs to be accurate.
• Be sure to complete social work contacts timely that were previously
started and missing required information.
• Information contained in special investigation reports should be consistent
with other documentation in the report.
• The date verbal summary of preliminary findings is provided starts the
clock for the timeframe special investigation reports must be completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
5

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the renewal
inspection completed on 10/13/2022 with a corrective action plan approved on
10/31/2022. During the review the agency had five violations. Three citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under
review the agency noted that overall compliance was impacted, in part, by the
previous year CAP not being reviewed as frequently as intended.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency experienced minimal difficulty in meeting
requirements during this review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the
previous year CAP did not appear to be reviewed as intended which led to
challenges related to overall compliance. The CA indicated the agency enhanced
checklists and increased supervisory oversight led to improvements regarding
licensing reevaluation reports as well as special investigations. The agency found
after the CAP was implemented the use of clerical support was ineffective and
inefficient. The CA expressed confidence that several areas will improve over the
next review period.
Financial Overview
NA
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors are available and coworkers assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns or areas of need.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Agency Analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert: Licensed foster home did not have any working smoke alarms. All
smoke alarms had been unplugged.
Resolution: Foster care worker conducted a home visit and ensured all smoke
alarms were plugged in and functioning properly. Pictures and a video were provided
as verification.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
6
